answer_verification.reasoning: The solution correctly traces the spatial transformation. Starting with the front cover facing up and title at top, a 180° forward flip around the horizontal axis rotates the book so the front cover faces down and the top edge becomes the bottom edge. The title ends up at the bottom, facing down against the desk. Options A, B, and C incorrectly describe either the orientation or position. Option E is clearly wrong as the position changes. Only D accurately describes both the final position (bottom) and orientation (facing down/against desk).

question_text: A transparent cube has a dot marked on one face. When you look through the cube from the opposite face, the dot appears to be in the center of your view. You then rotate the cube 90 degrees forward (tilting the top face toward you). From the same viewing position, where will the dot now appear?
answer_options: A) In the center of your view
B) At the top edge of your view
C) At the bottom edge of your view
D) The dot is no longer visible
E) At the left edge of your view
solution:
• Initially, the dot is on the face opposite to your viewing position, appearing centered
• When the cube rotates 90 degrees forward (top tilting toward you), the opposite face (with the dot) rotates backward
• The face that was opposite to you is now tilted away, with what was the center of that face now at the top portion of the visible area
• From your fixed viewing position through the transparent cube, the dot appears at the top edge
• Therefore, the answer is B because the 90-degree forward rotation moves the dot from center to the top edge of your view

visual_data.description: Two views of a transparent cube: (1) initial position showing a dot on the far face centered in view, (2) after 90-degree forward rotation showing the dot's new position at the top

visual_svg:

  <text x="250" y="25" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="16" font-weight="bold" text-anchor="middle" fill="#333">Cube Rotation: 90° Forward Around Horizontal Axis</text>
  
  <!-- Left cube - Initial Position -->

question_text: A cylindrical water bottle is lying on its side on a table. An ant starts at the point touching the table and walks in a straight line around the curved surface, always staying at the same height from the table, until it returns to its starting point. If the bottle has a radius of 3 cm, approximately how far does the ant walk?
solution:
• When the cylinder lies on its side, the ant walks around the circular cross-section at a constant height
• The ant traces a complete circle around the curved surface with radius 3 cm
• The circumference of a circle = 2 × π × radius = 2 × 3.14 × 3 = 18.84 cm
• Therefore, the answer is D because 18.84 cm is approximately 19 cm

question_text: A square pizza box is viewed from directly above. A slice has been removed from the top-left quarter of the pizza. If you rotate the box 180 degrees, in which quarter will the missing slice appear to be located?
solution:
• When rotating 180 degrees, every point moves to the opposite side of the center
• The top-left quarter is diagonally opposite to the bottom-right quarter
• After a 180-degree rotation, what was in the top-left will now be in the bottom-right
• Therefore, the answer is C because a 180-degree rotation moves the top-left position to the bottom-right position

question_text: A hexagonal gazebo has 6 equal sides. If the perimeter of the gazebo is 42 metres, what is the length of one side?
solution:
• The perimeter is the total distance around the hexagon
• Since the hexagon has 6 equal sides, we divide the perimeter by 6
• Length of one side = 42 ÷ 6 = 7 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because each side of the hexagonal gazebo is 7 metres long

question_text:
The table shows the number of pizzas sold by a restaurant on different days:

Day       | Pizzas Sold
Monday    | 32
Tuesday   | 28
Wednesday | 45
Thursday  | 38

How many pizzas were sold on Monday and Thursday combined?
solution:
• Find the number of pizzas sold on Monday: 32
• Find the number of pizzas sold on Thursday: 38
• Add these two values: 32 + 38 = 70
• Therefore, the answer is B because 70 pizzas were sold on Monday and Thursday combined.

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of sea creatures spotted during a diving expedition:

Sea Creature | Number Spotted
Dolphins      | 8
Sea Turtles   | 15
Stingrays     | 12
Octopuses     | 6

What fraction of the total sea creatures spotted were dolphins?
solution:
• First, find the total number of sea creatures spotted: 8 + 15 + 12 + 6 = 41
• Dolphins spotted: 8
• Fraction = 8/41
• Therefore, the answer is B because 8 out of 41 total sea creatures were dolphins, which simplifies to 8/41 (this fraction cannot be simplified further)

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of books borrowed from a library over three months:

Book Type | January | February | March
Fiction   | 156     | 132      | 168
Non-fiction | 84    | 96       | 72
Biography | 48      | 60       | 54

What percentage of the total books borrowed in February were Fiction books?
solution:
• Total books borrowed in February = 132 + 96 + 60 = 288
• Fiction books borrowed in February = 132
• Percentage = (132 ÷ 288) × 100 = 0.458333... × 100 = 45.8% (to 1 decimal place)
• Therefore, the answer is B because 132 out of 288 books represents 45.8% of the total

question_text: A six-pointed star (Star of David) is drawn with one point facing directly upward. If the star is rotated 60 degrees counterclockwise around its center, how many points will now be in exactly the same positions as they were before the rotation?
solution:
• A six-pointed star has rotational symmetry of order 6, meaning it looks identical after rotations of 60°, 120°, 180°, 240°, 300°, and 360°
• When rotated 60° counterclockwise, each point moves to where the next point was located
• Because of this perfect symmetry, the star appears unchanged - all 6 points are in positions that match the original configuration
• Therefore, the answer is E because all 6 points occupy positions that were previously occupied by other points, making the star look identical to its starting position

visual_data.description: A six-pointed star (hexagram) with one point at the top (12 o'clock position), showing rotational symmetry

answer_verification.reasoning: A six-pointed star has 6-fold rotational symmetry. A 60° rotation is 1/6 of a full rotation (360°/6 = 60°). After rotating 60° counterclockwise, each point moves to the position of the next point. Since all 6 points are identical and evenly spaced 60° apart, all 6 point positions are occupied by points (though different points than before). The question asks which points are 'in exactly the same positions as they were before' - and the answer is all 6 positions have points in them, matching the original configuration. The solution correctly identifies this as a consequence of the star's 6-fold rotational symmetry.

question_text: A standard six-sided die is placed on a table with the face showing 1 dot on top and the face showing 2 dots facing toward you. If you roll the die forward (away from you) exactly one quarter turn, which number will be on top?
solution:
• On a standard die, opposite faces always sum to 7 (1-6, 2-5, 3-4)
• Initially: top = 1, front (facing you) = 2
• Since top is 1, bottom must be 6 (opposite faces sum to 7)
• When rolling forward one quarter turn, the face that was facing you (2) becomes the top
• Wait - let me reconsider: rolling forward means the top face moves away, and the face that was facing away comes to top
• Initially: top = 1, front = 2, so back = 5 (since 2 is front, 5 must be back)
• Rolling forward: what was on back (5) comes to top
• Therefore, the answer is D because when rolling forward one quarter turn, the back face rotates to become the top face

answer_verification.reasoning: On a standard die, opposite faces sum to 7. Initial position: top=1, front=2, therefore back=5 (opposite of front). Rolling forward one quarter turn rotates the die away from you, bringing the back face to the top. Therefore 5 is correct. All other options are definitively wrong: 1 was on top initially, 2 is in front, 3 and 6 are on the sides, and 6 is on the bottom.

question_text: A cylindrical can is standing upright on a table. A label wraps completely around the can with a diagonal stripe that starts at point P on the bottom edge and ends at point Q on the top edge, making exactly one complete wrap around the can. If you were to 'unroll' the label into a flat rectangle, what shape would the stripe form?
solution:
• When a cylinder is unrolled into a flat rectangle, the bottom edge becomes one horizontal edge and the top edge becomes the opposite horizontal edge
• A stripe that wraps around the cylinder in a helical (spiral) pattern connects a point on one edge to a point on the opposite edge
• Since the stripe makes exactly one complete wrap, when flattened, it travels from point P on the bottom edge to point Q on the top edge in a straight path
• This creates a diagonal straight line across the rectangular surface
• Therefore, the answer is B because unrolling a helical path on a cylinder produces a straight diagonal line on the flat surface

answer_verification.reasoning: When a cylinder is unrolled into a flat rectangle, a helical stripe that makes exactly one complete wrap around the cylinder becomes a straight diagonal line. The stripe starts at point P on the bottom edge and ends at point Q on the top edge. Since it wraps exactly once, the horizontal distance traveled equals the circumference, and the vertical distance equals the height. When flattened, these create a diagonal straight line. All other options (horizontal, vertical, curved, or zigzag) are geometrically impossible for a single-wrap helix on an unrolled cylinder.

question_text: A cube is positioned so that you can see exactly three of its faces: the top, front, and right side. An arrow is painted on the front face pointing upward. If you rotate the entire cube 90 degrees forward (the top face moves toward you), which face will the arrow now be on, and in which direction will it point?
answer_options: A) Top face, pointing away from you
B) Top face, pointing toward you
C) Bottom face, pointing away from you
D) Bottom face, pointing toward you
solution:
• Initially, the arrow is on the front face pointing upward
• When rotating 90 degrees forward, the front face becomes the new top face
• During this rotation, what was pointing 'up' on the front face now points 'away from you' on the top face (the arrow rotates with the face)
• Therefore, the answer is A because the arrow ends up on the top face pointing away from you

parameters.marked_feature: arrow on front face pointing up

question_text: A square piece of paper has a circle drawn in its center. The paper is folded diagonally from the bottom-left corner to the top-right corner, then folded diagonally again from the bottom-right corner to the top-left corner. How many layers of paper will you find at the center point where the circle was originally drawn?
solution:
• Start with 1 layer (the original square paper)
• First diagonal fold: the paper is folded in half, creating 2 layers throughout the folded region
• Second diagonal fold: the already-folded paper is folded again, doubling the layers to 4
• The center point of the original square lies within the folded region after both folds
• Therefore, the answer is B because at the center point there are 4 layers of paper

question_text: A regular pentagonal prism (a 3D shape with two parallel pentagonal faces connected by five rectangular faces) is standing upright on a table with one pentagonal face as its base. If you were to look at this prism from directly above, then rotate your viewing position 72 degrees around the prism while keeping the same height, how would your view change?
answer_options: A) The view would look completely different
B) The view would look identical to the original
C) The view would be rotated 72 degrees
D) The view would be upside down
E) The view would show fewer sides
solution:
• A regular pentagon has 5 equal sides and 5-fold rotational symmetry
• When viewing from directly above, you see the pentagonal top face
• Rotating 72 degrees (which is 360° ÷ 5) around a regular pentagon produces an identical view due to its rotational symmetry
• Each vertex and edge of the pentagon moves to the position of the next one, making the shape appear unchanged
• Therefore, the answer is B because the view would look identical to the original

question_text: A trapezoidal piece of land is being fenced. The parallel sides measure 45 metres and 30 metres, and the non-parallel sides each measure 15 metres. What is the total length of fencing required?
solution:
• The perimeter of a trapezoid is the sum of all four sides
• Perimeter = 45 + 30 + 15 + 15
• Perimeter = 105 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total length of fencing needed equals the perimeter of the trapezoidal land

question_text: A circular running track has a radius of 35 metres. If an athlete runs exactly once around the track, how many metres does the athlete cover? (Use π = 22/7)
solution:
• The distance around a circle is its circumference
• Formula: Circumference = 2πr where r is the radius
• Circumference = 2 × (22/7) × 35
• Circumference = 2 × 22 × 5 = 220 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the athlete covers 220 metres in one complete lap

question_text: A cube-shaped storage container has a total surface area of 96 square centimetres. What is the length of one edge of the cube?
solution:
• A cube has 6 identical square faces
• Surface area of cube = 6 × (edge length)²
• 96 = 6 × (edge length)²
• (edge length)² = 96 ÷ 6 = 16
• edge length = √16 = 4 cm
• Therefore, the answer is B because each edge of the cube measures 4 cm

question_text:
The table shows the number of apps downloaded from different categories on a smartphone during one week:

Category | Downloads
Games    | 15
Education| 8
Music    | 12
Sports   | 5

How many apps were downloaded in total?
solution:
• Add all the downloads: 15 + 8 + 12 + 5
• 15 + 8 = 23
• 23 + 12 = 35
• 35 + 5 = 40
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total number of apps downloaded is 40

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of instruments played by students in a school orchestra:

Instrument | Number of Students
Violin     | 28
Flute      | 16
Clarinet   | 12
Trumpet    | 20
Cello      | 14

What fraction of the students play either violin or trumpet?
solution:
• First, find the total number of students: 28 + 16 + 12 + 20 + 14 = 90 students
• Find the number of students who play violin or trumpet: 28 + 20 = 48 students
• Calculate the fraction: 48/90
• Simplify by dividing both numerator and denominator by 6: 48 ÷ 6 = 8, and 90 ÷ 6 = 15
• Therefore, the answer is B because 8/15 of the students play either violin or trumpet

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of minerals extracted from three mines during a month:

Mine      | Iron (tonnes) | Copper (tonnes) | Gold (kg)
Northern  | 450          | 280            | 12
Eastern   | 520          | 195            | 18
Western   | 380          | 315            | 15

What is the total mass of copper extracted from the mine that produced the least iron?
solution:
• First, identify which mine produced the least iron: Northern = 450 tonnes, Eastern = 520 tonnes, Western = 380 tonnes
• The Western mine produced the least iron (380 tonnes)
• Find the copper extracted from the Western mine: 315 tonnes
• Therefore, the answer is B because the Western mine, which had the least iron production, extracted 315 tonnes of copper

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of fish caught by three fishing boats during one week:

Boat       | Snapper | Tuna | Mackerel
Blue Wave  | 45      | 28   | 36
Sea Breeze | 52      | 35   | 29
Ocean Star | 38      | 41   | 33

What percentage of the total fish caught by Blue Wave were Snapper?
solution:
• First, find the total fish caught by Blue Wave: 45 + 28 + 36 = 109
• Calculate the percentage of Snapper: (45 ÷ 109) × 100 = 41.28...
• Round to the nearest whole number: 41%
• Therefore, the answer is B because 41% of Blue Wave's total catch were Snapper

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of pastries sold by a bakery over three days:

Pastry Type | Thursday | Friday | Saturday
Croissants  | 45       | 52     | 68
Muffins     | 38       | 41     | 55
Danish      | 27       | 33     | 42

On which day was the total number of pastries sold exactly 126?
solution:
• Calculate total for Thursday: 45 + 38 + 27 = 110
• Calculate total for Friday: 52 + 41 + 33 = 126
• Calculate total for Saturday: 68 + 55 + 42 = 165
• Therefore, the answer is B because only Friday had exactly 126 pastries sold in total

question_text: A rectangular flag is hanging vertically from a flagpole with a blue triangle in the top-left corner and a red circle in the bottom-right corner. If the flag is rotated 180 degrees around its center point, where will the blue triangle be positioned?
solution:
• When an object is rotated 180 degrees around its center, every point moves to the opposite position
• The top-left corner becomes the bottom-right corner after a 180-degree rotation
• The blue triangle that was in the top-left will now be in the bottom-right corner
• Therefore, the answer is B because a 180-degree rotation moves each corner to its diagonally opposite position

question_text: A regular hexagon is drawn on paper with one vertex pointing directly upward (like a honeycomb cell). A line is drawn from the top vertex straight down to the bottom vertex, dividing the hexagon into two equal halves. How many sides does each half have?
solution:
• A regular hexagon has 6 vertices and 6 sides
• When a line is drawn from the top vertex to the bottom vertex, it passes through the center
• This line cuts through the hexagon, creating two new edges (one for each half)
• Each half consists of: 3 original sides of the hexagon + 1 new side (the dividing line) = 4 sides
• Therefore, the answer is B because each half is a quadrilateral with 4 sides

question_text: A triangular prism is lying on its side on a table, with one of its three rectangular faces flat against the table. Looking at it from the front, you see a rectangular face. If you rotate the prism 120 degrees around its length (the axis running through the centers of both triangular ends), which type of face will now be flat against the table?
answer_options: C) No face will be flat; it will balance on an edge
D) Either a triangular or rectangular face, depending on direction
E) The same rectangular face as before
solution:
• A triangular prism has 2 triangular faces (the ends) and 3 rectangular faces (the sides)
• When lying on its side, one of the 3 rectangular faces is against the table
• Rotating 120 degrees around the length axis moves the prism by exactly one-third of a full rotation (360 ÷ 3 = 120)
• Since there are 3 rectangular faces evenly spaced around the prism, a 120-degree rotation will bring the next rectangular face to the bottom
• Therefore, the answer is B because after a 120-degree rotation around its length, a different rectangular face will be flat against the table

question_text: A rectangular sheet of paper has a star drawn in the bottom-right corner. The paper is first folded in half vertically (bringing the right edge to meet the left edge), then folded in half horizontally (bringing the bottom edge to meet the top edge). After both folds, where will the star appear when you look at the folded paper?
answer_options: A) In the center of the folded paper
B) At the top-left corner of the folded paper
C) At the bottom-right corner of the folded paper
D) Hidden inside, not visible from outside
E) At the bottom-left corner of the folded paper
solution:
• Start with the star in the bottom-right corner of the rectangular paper
• First fold: Fold vertically (right edge to left edge). The star moves from bottom-right to bottom-left of the now-folded paper
• Second fold: Fold horizontally (bottom edge to top edge). The star moves from bottom-left to top-left of the twice-folded paper
• Therefore, the answer is B because after both folds, the star will be visible at the top-left corner of the folded paper

question_text: A square piece of cardboard has a black dot marked in the exact center of its top edge. The cardboard is rotated 270 degrees clockwise around its center point. Where will the black dot be located after this rotation?
answer_options: A) Center of the top edge
B) Center of the right edge
C) Center of the bottom edge
D) Center of the left edge
E) At the center of the square
solution:
• The dot starts at the center of the top edge
• A 270-degree clockwise rotation is the same as a 90-degree counterclockwise rotation
• When rotating clockwise: top → right → bottom → left
• After 270 degrees clockwise (or 3 quarter-turns), the top edge moves to the left position
• Therefore, the answer is D because the dot that was at the center of the top edge is now at the center of the left edge

question_text: A triangular sail has a base of 6 metres and a height of 8 metres. What is the area of the sail?
solution:
• Area of a triangle = ½ × base × height
• Area = ½ × 6 × 8
• Area = ½ × 48 = 24 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the triangular sail is 24 square metres

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of flowers sold by a florist on Saturday:

Flower Type | Number Sold
Roses       | 28
Tulips      | 35
Daisies     | 22
Lilies      | 19

How many flowers were sold in total?
solution:
• Add all the flowers sold: 28 + 35 + 22 + 19
• 28 + 35 = 63
• 63 + 22 = 85
• 85 + 19 = 104
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total number of flowers sold is 104

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of sandwiches sold by a café during lunch service:

Sandwich Type | Number Sold
Chicken       | 28
Vegetarian    | 15
Tuna          | 22
Ham           | 19

If the café made a profit of $3 on each sandwich sold, what was the total profit from all sandwiches?
solution:
• First, find the total number of sandwiches sold: 28 + 15 + 22 + 19 = 84 sandwiches
• Then multiply by the profit per sandwich: 84 × $3 = $252
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total profit from all sandwiches sold was $252

question_text:
The table shows the number of visitors to a museum on different days and their ticket types:

Day       | Adult | Child | Senior
Monday    | 45    | 28    | 17
Tuesday   | 52    | 35    | 21
Wednesday | 38    | 42    | 19

If adult tickets cost $15, child tickets cost $8, and senior tickets cost $10, what was the total revenue collected on Tuesday?
solution:
• Calculate revenue from adult tickets on Tuesday: 52 × $15 = $780
• Calculate revenue from child tickets on Tuesday: 35 × $8 = $280
• Calculate revenue from senior tickets on Tuesday: 21 × $10 = $210
• Add all revenues together: $780 + $280 + $210 = $1,070
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total revenue collected on Tuesday was $1,070

question_text:
The table shows the number of goals scored by players in a soccer tournament:

Player | Goals in Group Stage | Goals in Finals
Emma   | 5                    | 3
Jake   | 4                    | 2
Sofia  | 6                    | 4
Liam   | 3                    | 1

What percentage of the total goals were scored during the Finals stage?
solution:
• Total goals in Group Stage = 5 + 4 + 6 + 3 = 18
• Total goals in Finals = 3 + 2 + 4 + 1 = 10
• Total goals overall = 18 + 10 = 28
• Percentage in Finals = (10 ÷ 28) × 100 = 35.714...%
• Therefore, the answer is B because 35.7% rounds to 36%

question_text:
The table shows the temperature (in °C) recorded at a weather station at different times during one day:

Time        | Temperature (°C)
6:00 AM     | 8
9:00 AM     | 14
12:00 PM    | 22
3:00 PM     | 26
6:00 PM     | 18
9:00 PM     | 12

What was the mean temperature increase per 3-hour period from 6:00 AM to 3:00 PM?
solution:
• From 6:00 AM to 3:00 PM is 9 hours, which equals 3 periods of 3 hours each
• Temperature at 6:00 AM = 8°C, Temperature at 3:00 PM = 26°C
• Total increase = 26 - 8 = 18°C
• Mean increase per 3-hour period = 18 ÷ 3 = 6°C
• Therefore, the answer is B because the average temperature rose by 6°C every 3 hours during this time period

Mean per period is 18°C ÷ 3 = 6°C. The solution correctly identifies this as option B. All other options are mathematically incorrect for this specific problem.

question_text: A pyramid with a square base is standing upright on a table. The base has 4 corners and the pyramid has 1 point at the top. How many edges does this pyramid have in total?
solution:
• A square pyramid has a square base with 4 edges
• From each of the 4 corners of the base, an edge goes up to meet at the apex (top point)
• Total edges = 4 (base edges) + 4 (edges to apex) = 8 edges
• Therefore, the answer is D because the pyramid has 8 edges in total

question_text: A triangular sail on a boat is shaped like a right-angled triangle. The right angle is at the bottom-left corner, the longest side (hypotenuse) runs diagonally from bottom-left to top-right, and the sail has a red stripe along its bottom horizontal edge. If the sail is reflected across its vertical left edge (like flipping it along the mast), where will the red stripe be positioned?
answer_options: A) Along the bottom horizontal edge
B) Along the top horizontal edge
D) Along the vertical left edge
E) Along the vertical right edge
solution:
• When a shape is reflected across a vertical line (the left edge), the horizontal distances from that line are reversed
• The red stripe is along the bottom horizontal edge, which is perpendicular to the line of reflection
• After reflection, the stripe remains at the same height (bottom), but the triangle flips horizontally
• The bottom edge stays at the bottom, but now extends in the opposite horizontal direction
• Therefore, the answer is A because the red stripe remains along the bottom horizontal edge, just on the opposite side of the vertical line of reflection

The stripe remains along a bottom horizontal edge, making A correct. question_text: A pentagonal garden path is made up of 5 identical isosceles triangles arranged around a central point. Each triangle has two equal sides of 4 metres and a base of 6 metres. If the perpendicular height from the central point to each base is 2.5 metres, what is the total area of the pentagonal path?
solution:
• Each triangle has a base of 6 metres and height of 2.5 metres
• Area of one triangle = ½ × base × height = ½ × 6 × 2.5 = 7.5 m²
• Total area = 5 triangles × 7.5 m² = 37.5 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the pentagonal path consists of 5 identical triangles, each with area 7.5 m²

question_text: A rectangular book is lying flat on a desk with its front cover facing up. The title text runs horizontally across the top edge of the cover. The book is first flipped over its bottom edge (away from you), then rotated 90 degrees clockwise while lying flat. Where is the title text now positioned and in what orientation?
answer_options: A) At the left edge, reading upward from bottom to top
B) At the right edge, reading downward from top to bottom
C) At the top edge, reading right to left (upside down)
D) At the bottom edge, reading left to right (normal)
E) At the left edge, reading downward from top to bottom
solution:
• Start: Title at top edge, reading left to right, front cover up
• Flip over bottom edge: Book flips away from you - front cover now faces down, title at top edge but now reading right to left (upside down from underneath)
• Rotate 90° clockwise (while flat): The top edge moves to become the right edge
• Result: Title is now at the right edge. Since the cover is face-down and was upside-down, the text reads downward from top to bottom when viewed from above
• Therefore, the answer is B because after flipping and rotating, the title ends up on the right edge reading downward

question_text: A cylindrical water tank has a radius of 7 metres and a height of 10 metres. What is the volume of the water tank? (Use π = 22/7)
solution:
• Volume of cylinder = π × r² × h
• Volume = 22/7 × 7² × 10
• Volume = 22/7 × 49 × 10
• Volume = 22 × 7 × 10 = 1540 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the cylindrical water tank is 1540 cubic metres

visual_data.description: A simple 3D cylinder shown in perspective view, labeled with radius = 7 m on the circular top face and height = 10 m along the vertical side

question_text: A rectangular mirror is mounted on a wall. When you stand facing the mirror, your right hand appears on which side of your reflection?
answer_options: C) Same side as in reality
E) It depends on the distance
solution:
• A mirror creates a reflection that reverses the image horizontally (left-right flip)
• When you raise your right hand, it appears on the left side of your reflection when you look at the mirror
• This is because the mirror swaps the left and right sides of the image
• Therefore, the answer is B because your right hand appears on the left side of your reflection

visual_data.description: Simple diagram showing a stick figure facing a rectangular mirror, with the figure's right hand raised and the reflection showing the hand on the opposite side

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of coins in Emma's collection:

Coin Type | Number
5 cent    | 28
10 cent   | 42
20 cent   | 35
50 cent   | 15

How many coins does Emma have in total?
solution:
• Add all the coins: 28 + 42 + 35 + 15
• 28 + 42 = 70
• 70 + 35 = 105
• 105 + 15 = 120
• Therefore, the answer is B because Emma has 120 coins in total

question_text:
The table shows the number of hours different students spent on homework during one week:

Student | Hours
Oliver  | 8
Priya   | 12
Quinn   | 9
Ryan    | 15
Sofia   | 11

What is the difference between the total hours spent by the three students who studied the most and the total hours spent by the two students who studied the least?
solution:
• First, identify the three students who studied the most: Ryan (15), Priya (12), and Sofia (11)
• Calculate their total: 15 + 12 + 11 = 38 hours
• Next, identify the two students who studied the least: Oliver (8) and Quinn (9)
• Calculate their total: 8 + 9 = 17 hours
• Find the difference: 38 - 17 = 21 hours
• Therefore, the answer is B because the difference between the two groups is 21 hours

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of trees planted in a community garden over four seasons:

Tree Type | Spring | Summer | Autumn | Winter
Oak       | 15     | 8      | 12     | 6
Maple     | 18     | 10     | 9      | 5
Pine      | 12     | 14     | 11     | 8

What fraction of all the trees planted were Maple trees?
solution:
• First, calculate total Maple trees: 18 + 10 + 9 + 5 = 42
• Next, calculate total trees of all types: Oak = 15 + 8 + 12 + 6 = 41; Maple = 42; Pine = 12 + 14 + 11 + 8 = 45
• Total all trees = 41 + 42 + 45 = 128
• Fraction of Maple trees = 42/128 = 21/64 (simplified by dividing both numerator and denominator by 2)
• Therefore, the answer is B because 21/64 represents the simplified fraction of Maple trees out of all trees planted

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of gemstones collected by a geology museum from three different regions:

Region | Emeralds | Sapphires | Rubies
North  | 24       | 36        | 18
South  | 32       | 28        | 22
East   | 16       | 44        | 26

What percentage of the total sapphires collected came from the East region?
solution:
• Total sapphires from North = 36
• Total sapphires from South = 28
• Total sapphires from East = 44
• Total sapphires collected = 36 + 28 + 44 = 108
• Percentage from East = (44 ÷ 108) × 100 = 40.74%
• Therefore, the answer is B because 40.7% (rounded to one decimal place) of the total sapphires came from the East region

question_text: A rectangular pizza box measures 8 units wide by 12 units tall when viewed from above. A circular grease stain is located 2 units from the left edge and 3 units from the top edge. If the box is rotated 180 degrees around its center point, how far will the grease stain be from the top edge in its new position?
solution:
• The box is 12 units tall, so its center is 6 units from both the top and bottom edges
• The stain starts 3 units from the top edge, which means it is 9 units from the bottom edge
• A 180-degree rotation around the center point swaps the positions: what was near the top moves to near the bottom, and vice versa
• After rotation, the stain will be 9 units from the new top edge (which was the original bottom edge)
• Therefore, the answer is D because the stain moves from 3 units to 9 units from the top edge

question_text: A rectangular postcard measuring 3 units wide by 5 units tall has a stamp in the top-right corner. The postcard is rotated 180 degrees around its center point. Where is the stamp now located?
solution:
• When an object is rotated 180 degrees around its center point, every point moves to the opposite position
• The top-right corner becomes the bottom-left corner
• The top-left corner becomes the bottom-right corner
• Therefore, the answer is C because a 180-degree rotation moves the stamp from the top-right corner to the bottom-left corner

question_text: A dice is placed on a table showing 5 dots on the top face and 2 dots on the front face (facing you). On a standard dice, opposite faces always add up to 7. If you roll the dice forward one quarter turn (90 degrees toward you), which number will now be on the top face?
solution:
• Initially, the top face shows 5 and the front face shows 2
• When rolling the dice forward (toward you) by 90 degrees, the front face (2) moves to become the new top face
• The original top face (5) moves to become the new back face
• Therefore, the answer is B because the face showing 2 dots rotates to the top position

question_text: A cylindrical water tank is standing upright. Looking from above, you see a circular opening. A ladder is painted on the curved outer surface of the tank, running from bottom to top. If you walk around the tank in a clockwise direction (when viewed from above) through 90 degrees, the ladder that was directly in front of you will now be:
answer_options: A) Directly in front of you
E) No longer visible from any angle
solution:
• When you walk clockwise around the tank through 90 degrees, you are moving to your right
• The tank and ladder remain stationary - only your viewing position changes
• If the ladder was directly in front of you initially, after you move 90 degrees clockwise, you have moved to where your right side was pointing
• From this new position, the ladder (which hasn't moved) is now 90 degrees counterclockwise from your front view
• Therefore, the answer is D because the ladder is now on your left side

visual_data.description: Top-down view of a circular tank with a dot representing the viewer's initial position outside the tank, and a mark on the circle's edge showing the ladder position. An arrow shows the 90-degree clockwise movement path of the viewer around the tank.

question_text:
A swimming pool uses different amounts of chlorine tablets based on pool size and water temperature. The table shows the daily tablet requirements:

| Pool Size | Base Tablets | Per 10°C above 20°C |
|-----------|--------------|---------------------|
| Small | 2 | 1 |
| Medium | 3 | 1.5 |
| Large | 4 | 2 |

A medium pool has a water temperature of 30°C. How many tablets are needed for 5 days?
solution:
• Temperature above 20°C: 30°C - 20°C = 10°C
• Daily tablets for medium pool: 3 + (1.5 × 1) = 3 + 1.5 = 4.5 tablets
• Tablets for 5 days: 4.5 × 5 = 22.5 tablets
• Therefore, the answer is B because the medium pool at 30°C requires 4.5 tablets per day, which totals 22.5 tablets over 5 days

answer_verification.reasoning: The calculation is straightforward and unambiguous. Temperature difference: 30°C - 20°C = 10°C (which equals one 10°C increment). No reasonable interpretation of the problem yields these alternatives.

question_text:
A toy store tracks the number of building block sets sold over four weeks. The table shows the sales data:

| Week | Small Sets | Medium Sets | Large Sets |
|------|------------|-------------|------------|
| 1    | 12         | 8           | 5          |
| 2    | 15         | 10          | 4          |
| 3    | 10         | 12          | 6          |
| 4    | 18         | 9           | 7          |

How many medium sets were sold in total across all four weeks?
solution:
• Find the Medium Sets column in the table
• Add the values for all four weeks: 8 + 10 + 12 + 9 = 39
• Therefore, the answer is B because 39 medium sets were sold in total

question_text: A cylindrical water tank has a radius of 3 metres and a height of 5 metres. What is the volume of water it can hold when completely filled? (Use π ≈ 3.14)
solution:
• Volume of a cylinder = π × r² × h
• Substitute the values: V = 3.14 × 3² × 5
• Calculate: V = 3.14 × 9 × 5 = 3.14 × 45 = 141.3 m³
• Therefore, the answer is C because the volume of the cylindrical tank is 141.3 cubic metres

question_text: A right-angled triangular prism has a triangular face with perpendicular sides of 6 cm and 8 cm. The prism has a length of 15 cm. What is the total surface area of the prism?
solution:
• First, find the hypotenuse of the right-angled triangle using Pythagoras' theorem: √(6² + 8²) = √(36 + 64) = √100 = 10 cm
• Area of each triangular face = ½ × 6 × 8 = 24 cm². There are 2 triangular faces, so total = 2 × 24 = 48 cm²
• The three rectangular faces have dimensions: (6 × 15), (8 × 15), and (10 × 15)
• Area of rectangular faces = 90 + 120 + 150 = 360 cm²
• Total surface area = 48 + 360 = 432 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is C because the total surface area includes both triangular ends and all three rectangular side faces

question_text: A triangular sail on a yacht has a base of 4.5 metres and a height of 8 metres. What is the area of the sail?
solution:
• Area of a triangle = ½ × base × height
• Area = ½ × 4.5 × 8
• Area = ½ × 36 = 18 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the triangular sail is 18 m²

question_text: A basketball court has a rectangular playing area with a length of 28 metres and a width of 15 metres. What is the perimeter of the playing area?
solution:
• Perimeter of a rectangle = 2 × (length + width)
• Perimeter = 2 × (28 + 15)
• Perimeter = 2 × 43 = 86 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the perimeter is the total distance around the rectangular court, which equals 86 metres.

question_text: A rectangular garden bed is 8 metres long and 6 metres wide. A path of uniform width 1 metre runs around the outside of the garden bed. What is the total area of the path?
solution:
• The garden bed has dimensions 8 m × 6 m, so its area = 8 × 6 = 48 m²
• With a 1 m path around it, the outer rectangle has dimensions (8 + 2) m × (6 + 2) m = 10 m × 8 m
• Area of outer rectangle = 10 × 8 = 80 m²
• Area of path = Area of outer rectangle - Area of garden bed = 80 - 48 = 32 m²
• Therefore, the answer is C because the path covers 32 square metres

question_text: A square picture frame has sides of length 15 cm. What is the perimeter of the frame?
solution:
• The perimeter of a square is calculated by adding all four sides: P = 4 × side length
• P = 4 × 15 cm = 60 cm
• Therefore, the answer is C because the perimeter of the square frame is 60 cm

question_text: A chocolate box is designed in the shape of a regular hexagonal prism. The hexagonal base has a side length of 4 cm and an apothem (perpendicular distance from centre to side) of 3.46 cm. If the height of the box is 6 cm, what is the volume of the chocolate box?
solution:
• First, find the area of the hexagonal base using: Area = (1/2) × perimeter × apothem
• Perimeter of hexagon = 6 × 4 = 24 cm
• Area of hexagonal base = (1/2) × 24 × 3.46 = 12 × 3.46 = 41.52 cm²
• Volume of prism = base area × height = 41.52 × 6 = 249.12 cm³
• Therefore, the answer is C because the volume of the hexagonal prism is 249.12 cm³

question_text: A pizza restaurant cuts a circular pizza with diameter 28 cm into 8 equal slices. What is the area of one slice? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• First, find the radius: radius = diameter ÷ 2 = 28 ÷ 2 = 14 cm
• Calculate the total area of the pizza: Area = πr² = (22/7) × 14² = (22/7) × 196 = 22 × 28 = 616 cm²
• Divide by the number of slices: Area of one slice = 616 ÷ 8 = 77 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is B because one slice has an area of 77 cm²

question_text:
The table shows the number of visitors to a science museum over four days:

Day       | Visitors
Thursday  | 245
Friday    | 318
Saturday  | 492
Sunday    | 385

How many more visitors attended on the weekend (Saturday and Sunday combined) than on the weekdays (Thursday and Friday combined)?
solution:
• First, calculate total weekend visitors: 492 + 385 = 877
• Then, calculate total weekday visitors: 245 + 318 = 563
• Find the difference: 877 - 563 = 314
• Therefore, the answer is B because there were 314 more visitors on the weekend than on the weekdays

question_text:
The line graph shows the temperature recorded at a weather station over 6 hours:

Time    | Temperature (°C)
8:00 AM | 12
9:00 AM | 15
10:00 AM| 18
11:00 AM| 22
12:00 PM| 25
1:00 PM | 23

Between which two consecutive hours was the rate of temperature change the greatest?
solution:
• Calculate the temperature change for each consecutive hour:
• 8:00 AM to 9:00 AM: 15 - 12 = 3°C
• 9:00 AM to 10:00 AM: 18 - 15 = 3°C
• 10:00 AM to 11:00 AM: 22 - 18 = 4°C
• 11:00 AM to 12:00 PM: 25 - 22 = 3°C
• 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM: 23 - 25 = -2°C (decrease)
• The greatest rate of change (considering absolute value or increase) is 4°C between 10:00 AM and 11:00 AM.
• Therefore, the answer is C because the temperature increased by 4°C during this period, which is the largest change.

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of trees planted in a community park:

Tree Type | Number Planted
Oak       | 24
Maple     | 36
Pine      | 18
Birch     | 30

What percentage of the total trees planted were Maple trees?
solution:
• First, find the total number of trees: 24 + 36 + 18 + 30 = 108 trees
• Maple trees planted: 36
• Percentage = (36 ÷ 108) × 100 = 0.333... × 100 = 33.3%
• Therefore, the answer is B because Maple trees represent 33.3% of all trees planted

question_text:
The table shows the number of pages read by four students during a reading challenge:

Student | Pages Read
Olivia  | 156
Jack    | 142
Mia     | 168
Noah    | 134

How many more pages did Mia read than Noah?
solution:
• Find the number of pages Mia read: 168 pages
• Find the number of pages Noah read: 134 pages
• Calculate the difference: 168 - 134 = 34 pages
• Therefore, the answer is B because Mia read 34 more pages than Noah

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of birds spotted during a nature walk:

Bird Type | Number Spotted
Sparrow   | 12

Magpie    | 5
Parrot    | 3

How many more sparrows than parrots were spotted?
solution:
• Number of sparrows spotted = 12
• Number of parrots spotted = 3
• Difference = 12 - 3 = 9
• Therefore, the answer is B because 9 more sparrows than parrots were spotted.

question_text: A ladder is leaning against a vertical wall. The base of the ladder is 2.4 metres from the wall, and the top of the ladder reaches 3.2 metres up the wall. What is the length of the ladder?
solution:
• The ladder, wall, and ground form a right-angled triangle
• Using Pythagoras' theorem: c² = a² + b²
• Length² = 2.4² + 3.2² = 5.76 + 10.24 = 16
• Length = √16 = 4 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the ladder is 4.0 metres long

question_text: A swimming pool has a rectangular surface with length 25 metres and width 10 metres. The pool has a constant depth of 2 metres throughout. What is the volume of water the pool can hold?
solution:
• Volume of a rectangular prism = length × width × height
• Volume = 25 × 10 × 2
• Volume = 500 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the pool can hold 500 cubic metres of water

question_text: A tent is designed in the shape of a triangular prism. The triangular front face has a base of 3 metres and a height of 2 metres. The tent is 4 metres long. What is the volume of the tent?
solution:
• Volume of a triangular prism = Area of triangular face × length
• Area of triangular face = ½ × base × height = ½ × 3 × 2 = 3 m²
• Volume = 3 × 4 = 12 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the tent is 12 m³

question_text: A bookshelf has a back panel in the shape of a rectangle with length 120 cm and width 40 cm. What is the area of the back panel?
solution:
• Area of rectangle = length × width
• Area = 120 cm × 40 cm = 4800 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the rectangular back panel is 4800 cm²

question_text: A rectangular piece of paper measures 30 cm by 20 cm. A square with side length 8 cm is cut from each of the four corners. The paper is then folded up along the cuts to form an open-top box. What is the volume of this box?
solution:
• When squares of side 8 cm are cut from each corner and the paper is folded up, the height of the box becomes 8 cm
• The length of the box base = 30 - 2(8) = 30 - 16 = 14 cm
• The width of the box base = 20 - 2(8) = 20 - 16 = 4 cm
• Volume = length × width × height = 14 × 4 × 8 = 1792 cm³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the open-top box is 1792 cm³

question_text: A trapezium-shaped window has parallel sides of length 2.4 metres and 1.6 metres. The perpendicular distance between these parallel sides is 1.5 metres. What is the area of the window?
solution:
• Area of trapezium = ½ × (sum of parallel sides) × height
• Area = ½ × (2.4 + 1.6) × 1.5
• Area = ½ × 4.0 × 1.5 = 2.0 × 1.5 = 3.0 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the trapezium-shaped window is 3.0 m²

question_text: A cylindrical candle has a diameter of 6 cm and a height of 10 cm. What is the volume of wax needed to make the candle? (Use π ≈ 3.14)
solution:
• The radius of the cylinder is diameter ÷ 2 = 6 ÷ 2 = 3 cm
• Volume of cylinder = π × r² × h = 3.14 × 3² × 10
• Volume = 3.14 × 9 × 10 = 282.6 cm³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of wax needed is 282.6 cm³

question_text:
The table shows the number of medals won by different countries at a swimming championship:

Country   | Gold | Silver | Bronze
Australia | 12   | 8      | 6
Japan     | 9    | 11     | 7
USA       | 15   | 10     | 9
Canada    | 6    | 9      | 8

Which country won the greatest total number of medals?
solution:
• Calculate total medals for each country:
• Australia: 12 + 8 + 6 = 26 medals
• Japan: 9 + 11 + 7 = 27 medals
• USA: 15 + 10 + 9 = 34 medals
• Canada: 6 + 9 + 8 = 23 medals
• Therefore, the answer is C because USA won 34 medals, which is the greatest total

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of books borrowed from a library during one week:

Book Type | Number Borrowed
Fiction   | 156
Non-fiction | 84
Biography | 72
Science   | 48

What percentage of the total borrowed books were Fiction books?
solution:
• First, calculate the total number of books borrowed: 156 + 84 + 72 + 48 = 360
• Then calculate the percentage of Fiction books: (156 ÷ 360) × 100 = 0.4333... × 100 = 43.3%
• Therefore, the answer is B because Fiction books represent 43.3% of all borrowed books

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of fruits sold at a market stall on Monday:

Fruit Type | Number Sold
Apples     | 42
Oranges    | 38
Bananas    | 55
Grapes     | 29

How many more bananas than grapes were sold?
solution:
• Find the number of bananas sold: 55
• Find the number of grapes sold: 29
• Calculate the difference: 55 - 29 = 26
• Therefore, the answer is B because 26 more bananas than grapes were sold

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of vehicles that passed through a toll booth in one hour:

Vehicle Type | Number
Cars         | 45
Trucks       | 18
Motorcycles  | 12
Buses        | 5

How many more cars than trucks passed through the toll booth?
solution:
• Number of cars = 45
• Number of trucks = 18
• Difference = 45 - 18 = 27
• Therefore, the answer is B because 27 more cars than trucks passed through the toll booth.

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of items recycled by a school over three months:

| Material  | January | February | March |
|-----------|---------|----------|-------|
| Paper     | 145 kg  | 168 kg   | 152 kg|
| Plastic   | 87 kg   | 95 kg    | 103 kg|
| Glass     | 62 kg   | 58 kg    | 70 kg |
| Metal     | 34 kg   | 41 kg    | 37 kg |

What percentage of the total recycled materials in February was plastic? (Round to the nearest whole number)
solution:
• First, calculate the total materials recycled in February: 168 + 95 + 58 + 41 = 362 kg
• Plastic recycled in February was 95 kg
• Calculate the percentage: (95 ÷ 362) × 100 = 26.24...
• Round to the nearest whole number: 26%
• Therefore, the answer is B because plastic represented 26% of the total materials recycled in February

question_text: A running track consists of a rectangle with a semicircle at each end. The rectangular section has a length of 80 metres and a width of 60 metres. What is the total perimeter of the track? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• The track has two straight sides of 80 m each and two semicircular ends
• The two semicircles together form a complete circle with diameter = 60 m
• Circumference of circle = π × diameter = (22/7) × 60 = 1320/7 ≈ 188.57 m
• Total perimeter = 2 × 80 + 188.57 = 160 + 188.57 = 348.57 m ≈ 348 m
• Therefore, the answer is B because the perimeter includes two straight sections and one complete circular path

question_text: A triangular piece of land has sides measuring 13 metres, 14 metres, and 15 metres. What is the area of this land? (Hint: Use Heron's formula where area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)] and s is the semi-perimeter)
solution:
• First, calculate the semi-perimeter: s = (13 + 14 + 15) ÷ 2 = 42 ÷ 2 = 21 metres
• Apply Heron's formula: Area = √[21(21-13)(21-14)(21-15)]
• Area = √[21 × 8 × 7 × 6] = √7056 = 84 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the triangular land is 84 m²

question_text: A cone-shaped paper cup has a radius of 3.5 cm and a slant height of 12.5 cm. What is the curved surface area of the cup? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• Curved surface area of a cone = π × r × l, where r is the radius and l is the slant height
• Curved surface area = (22/7) × 3.5 × 12.5
• = (22/7) × 43.75 = 22 × 6.25 = 137.5 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the curved surface area of the cone is 137.5 cm²

question_text: A circular flower bed has a radius of 7 metres. What is the area of the flower bed? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• Area of circle = π × r²
• Area = (22/7) × 7² = (22/7) × 49
• Area = 22 × 7 = 154 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the circular flower bed is 154 m²

question_text: A greenhouse is built in the shape of a rectangular prism with a pyramid on top. The rectangular base measures 6 metres by 4 metres, and the height of the rectangular section is 3 metres. The pyramid has a height of 2 metres. What is the total volume of the greenhouse?
solution:
• Volume of rectangular prism = length × width × height = 6 × 4 × 3 = 72 m³
• Volume of pyramid = (1/3) × base area × height = (1/3) × (6 × 4) × 2 = (1/3) × 24 × 2 = 16 m³
• Total volume = 72 + 16 = 88 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total volume is the sum of the rectangular prism and the pyramid on top.

question_text: A water tank is in the shape of a cylinder with a radius of 1.4 metres and a height of 3 metres. What is the volume of water the tank can hold when full? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• Volume of cylinder = π × r² × h
• Volume = (22/7) × (1.4)² × 3
• Volume = (22/7) × 1.96 × 3
• Volume = (22/7) × 5.88 = 22 × 0.84 = 18.48 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the cylindrical water tank is 18.48 m³

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of stamps collected by three friends:

| Collector | Animal Stamps | Flower Stamps | Space Stamps |
|-----------|---------------|---------------|-------------|
| Hassan    | 24            | 18            | 12          |
| Priya     | 15            | 22            | 19          |
| Tom       | 31            | 14            | 16          |

How many stamps does Hassan have in total?
solution:
• Hassan has 24 Animal Stamps, 18 Flower Stamps, and 12 Space Stamps
• Total = 24 + 18 + 12 = 54
• Therefore, the answer is B because Hassan has 54 stamps in total

question_text:
The table shows the number of customers who visited a cinema on different days of the week:

| Day       | Customers |
|-----------|----------|
| Monday    | 145      |
| Tuesday   | 128      |
| Wednesday | 156      |
| Thursday  | 142      |
| Friday    | 189      |

How many more customers visited on Friday than on Tuesday?
solution:
• Find the number of customers on Friday: 189
• Find the number of customers on Tuesday: 128
• Calculate the difference: 189 - 128 = 61
• Therefore, the answer is B because 61 more customers visited on Friday than on Tuesday

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of drinks sold at a school canteen during lunchtime:

| Drink Type | Number Sold |
|------------|-------------|
| Water      | 45          |
| Juice      | 32          |
| Milk       | 28          |

How many more bottles of water were sold than milk?
solution:
• Find the number of water bottles sold: 45
• Find the number of milk bottles sold: 28
• Calculate the difference: 45 - 28 = 17
• Therefore, the answer is B because 17 more bottles of water were sold than milk

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of marine animals observed during three diving expeditions:

| Animal Type | Expedition 1 | Expedition 2 | Expedition 3 |
|-------------|--------------|--------------|-------------|
| Dolphins    | 8            | 12           | 6           |
| Turtles     | 15           | 9            | 18          |
| Sharks      | 3            | 5            | 7           |
| Rays        | 11           | 14           | 10          |

What is the ratio of the total number of Dolphins observed across all expeditions to the total number of Sharks observed across all expeditions?
solution:
• Total Dolphins = 8 + 12 + 6 = 26
• Total Sharks = 3 + 5 + 7 = 15
• Ratio of Dolphins to Sharks = 26:15
• This ratio cannot be simplified further as 26 and 15 share no common factors
• Therefore, the answer is B because the ratio is 26:15

Option B is definitively correct. Option A (13:15) is incorrect - it's half the dolphins. Option C (15:26) reverses the ratio. Option D (2:1) simplifies to 2:1 which equals 30:15, not 26:15. Option E is incorrect since B is valid.

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of plants sold at a garden centre over three days:

| Plant Type | Thursday | Friday | Saturday |
|------------|----------|--------|----------|
| Roses      | 24       | 30     | 36       |
| Tulips     | 18       | 22     | 28       |
| Daisies    | 12       | 15     | 18       |

What was the total number of Roses and Tulips sold on Friday?
solution:
• Find the number of Roses sold on Friday: 30
• Find the number of Tulips sold on Friday: 22
• Add these together: 30 + 22 = 52
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total number of Roses and Tulips sold on Friday is 52

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of musical instruments rented from a music store over four weeks:

| Instrument | Week 1 | Week 2 | Week 3 | Week 4 |
|------------|--------|--------|--------|--------|
| Guitar     | 12     | 15     | 18     | 13     |
| Piano      | 8      | 10     | 9      | 11     |
| Violin     | 6      | 7      | 8      | 9      |
| Drums      | 5      | 6      | 7      | 6      |

What was the percentage increase in total rentals from Week 1 to Week 3?
solution:
• Week 1 total: 12 + 8 + 6 + 5 = 31 rentals
• Week 3 total: 18 + 9 + 8 + 7 = 42 rentals
• Increase: 42 - 31 = 11 rentals
• Percentage increase: (11 ÷ 31) × 100 = 35.48...% ≈ 35.5%
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total rentals increased by approximately 35.5% from Week 1 to Week 3

question_text:
The table shows the number of emails received by an office worker on different days:

| Day       | Emails |
|-----------|--------|
| Monday    | 34     |
| Tuesday   | 28     |
| Wednesday | 41     |
| Thursday  | 35     |

How many more emails were received on Wednesday than on Tuesday?
solution:
• Find the number of emails received on Wednesday: 41
• Find the number of emails received on Tuesday: 28
• Calculate the difference: 41 − 28 = 13
• Therefore, the answer is B because 13 more emails were received on Wednesday than on Tuesday

question_text: A chocolate bar is in the shape of a triangular prism. The triangular cross-section has a base of 6 cm and a height of 4 cm. The length of the prism is 15 cm. What is the volume of the chocolate bar?
solution:
• Volume of a prism = Area of cross-section × length
• Area of triangular cross-section = ½ × base × height = ½ × 6 × 4 = 12 cm²
• Volume = 12 × 15 = 180 cm³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the triangular prism is 180 cm³

question_text: A smartphone screen protector is shaped like a rectangle with a length of 15 cm and a width of 7 cm. Two circular holes with diameter 1 cm each are cut out for the camera and sensor. What is the area of the screen protector after the holes are cut out? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• Area of rectangle = length × width = 15 × 7 = 105 cm²
• Radius of each circular hole = diameter ÷ 2 = 1 ÷ 2 = 0.5 cm
• Area of one circular hole = π × r² = (22/7) × 0.5² = (22/7) × 0.25 = 5.5/7 cm²
• Area of two circular holes = 2 × (5.5/7) = 11/7 ≈ 1.43 cm²
• Area of screen protector = 105 - 1.43 = 103.57 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the final area is the rectangle area minus the two circular holes

question_text: A storage container is shaped like a rectangular prism with a length of 2.5 metres, a width of 1.6 metres, and a height of 2 metres. What is the volume of the container?
solution:
• Volume of rectangular prism = length × width × height
• Volume = 2.5 × 1.6 × 2
• Volume = 4.0 × 2 = 8.0 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the container is 8.0 cubic metres

question_text: A decorative mirror frame consists of a large square with side length 50 cm and a smaller square hole in the centre with side length 30 cm. What is the area of the frame itself (the shaded region)?
solution:
• Area of large square = 50 × 50 = 2500 cm²
• Area of small square hole = 30 × 30 = 900 cm²
• Area of frame = Area of large square - Area of small square = 2500 - 900 = 1600 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the frame area is found by subtracting the hole area from the total area

question_text: A pizza box is in the shape of a square with side length 35 cm. What is the perimeter of the pizza box?
solution:
• Perimeter of a square = 4 × side length
• Perimeter = 4 × 35 = 140 cm
• Therefore, the answer is B because the perimeter of the square pizza box is 140 cm

question_text: A metal washer is in the shape of a circular disc with a circular hole in the centre. The outer radius of the washer is 2.1 cm and the inner radius (the hole) is 0.7 cm. What is the area of the metal washer? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• Area of outer circle = π × r² = (22/7) × (2.1)² = (22/7) × 4.41 = 13.86 cm²
• Area of inner circle (hole) = π × r² = (22/7) × (0.7)² = (22/7) × 0.49 = 1.54 cm²
• Area of washer = Area of outer circle - Area of inner circle = 13.86 - 1.54 = 12.32 cm²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the metal area is found by subtracting the hole area from the total disc area

question_text: A rectangular swimming pool has a length of 25 metres and a width of 12 metres. What is the perimeter of the swimming pool?
solution:
• Perimeter of a rectangle = 2 × (length + width)
• Perimeter = 2 × (25 + 12)
• Perimeter = 2 × 37 = 74 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the perimeter is calculated by adding all four sides of the rectangle, which equals 74 metres

question_text: A ladder is leaning against a wall. The base of the ladder is 2.4 metres away from the wall, and the top of the ladder reaches 3.2 metres up the wall. What is the length of the ladder?
solution:
• This is a right-angled triangle problem where we need to use Pythagoras' theorem: a² + b² = c²
• The distance from the wall is 2.4 m and the height up the wall is 3.2 m
• Ladder length² = 2.4² + 3.2² = 5.76 + 10.24 = 16
• Ladder length = √16 = 4.0 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the ladder forms the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle with length 4.0 metres

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of apps downloaded from a digital store over three days:

| App Type | Monday | Tuesday | Wednesday |
|----------|--------|---------|----------|
| Games    | 45     | 52      | 38       |
| Education| 28     | 35      | 42       |
| Music    | 33     | 29      | 31       |

What is the total number of Education apps downloaded over the three days?
solution:
• Identify Education app downloads: Monday = 28, Tuesday = 35, Wednesday = 42
• Add the three values: 28 + 35 + 42 = 105
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total number of Education apps downloaded over the three days is 105

question_text:
The table shows the number of visitors to a museum on different days and their ticket types:

| Day       | Adult Tickets | Child Tickets | Senior Tickets |
|-----------|---------------|---------------|----------------|
| Thursday  | 45            | 32            | 18             |
| Friday    | 52            | 28            | 22             |
| Saturday  | 78            | 64            | 31             |
| Sunday    | 71            | 58            | 26             |

If adult tickets cost $15, child tickets cost $8, and senior tickets cost $10, what was the total revenue collected on Saturday?
solution:
• Calculate revenue from adult tickets: 78 × $15 = $1170
• Calculate revenue from child tickets: 64 × $8 = $512
• Calculate revenue from senior tickets: 31 × $10 = $310
• Total revenue = $1170 + $512 + $310 = $1682
• Therefore, the answer is C because the total revenue collected on Saturday was $1682

question_text:
The table shows the temperature recorded at different times during a school day:

| Time  | Temperature (°C) |
|-------|------------------|
| 9 am  | 16               |
| 11 am | 22               |
| 1 pm  | 25               |
| 3 pm  | 23               |

What was the difference between the highest and lowest temperatures recorded?
solution:
• Identify the highest temperature: 25°C (at 1 pm)
• Identify the lowest temperature: 16°C (at 9 am)
• Calculate the difference: 25 - 16 = 9°C
• Therefore, the answer is B because the difference between the highest and lowest temperatures is 9°C

question_text:
The table shows the number of points scored by a basketball team in each quarter of a game:

| Quarter | Points Scored |
|---------|---------------|
| 1st     | 18            |
| 2nd     | 24            |
| 3rd     | 15            |
| 4th     | 27            |

If the opposing team scored 79 points in total, by how many points did this team win or lose the game?
solution:
• First, calculate the total points scored by this team: 18 + 24 + 15 + 27 = 84 points
• The opposing team scored 79 points
• Find the difference: 84 - 79 = 5 points
• Since 84 > 79, this team won by 5 points
• Therefore, the answer is A because the team scored 84 points compared to the opponent's 79 points, winning by 5 points

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of trees planted in a park over two years:

| Tree Type | 2022 | 2023 |
|-----------|------|------|
| Oak       | 45   | 38   |
| Maple     | 32   | 41   |
| Pine      | 28   | 35   |

How many trees in total were planted in 2023?
solution:
• Identify the number of each tree type planted in 2023: Oak = 38, Maple = 41, Pine = 35
• Add these values together: 38 + 41 + 35 = 114
• Therefore, the answer is B because 114 trees were planted in total in 2023

question_text:
The table shows the number of goals scored by a soccer team in five matches:

| Match | Goals Scored |
|-------|-------------|
| 1     | 3           |
| 2     | 1           |
| 3     | 4           |
| 4     | 2           |
| 5     | 5           |

How many goals did the team score in total across all five matches?
solution:
• Add all the goals scored across the five matches
• Total = 3 + 1 + 4 + 2 + 5 = 15
• Therefore, the answer is B because the team scored 15 goals in total

question_text:
The table shows the number of hours different students spent on homework during one week:

| Student | Hours |
|---------|-------|
| Lucas   | 8     |
| Maya    | 12    |
| Noah    | 10    |
| Olivia  | 14    |

How many more hours did Olivia spend on homework than Lucas?
solution:
• Find Lucas's homework hours: 8 hours
• Find Olivia's homework hours: 14 hours
• Calculate the difference: 14 - 8 = 6 hours
• Therefore, the answer is B because Olivia spent 6 more hours on homework than Lucas

question_text: A tent is in the shape of a triangular prism. The triangular face has a base of 3 metres and a height of 2 metres. The tent is 4 metres long. What is the volume of the tent?
solution:
• Volume of triangular prism = Area of triangular face × length
• Area of triangular face = ½ × base × height = ½ × 3 × 2 = 3 m²
• Volume = 3 × 4 = 12 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the tent is 12 m³

question_text: A basketball court has a rectangular playing area with a length of 28 metres and a width of 15 metres. What is the area of the playing surface?
solution:
• Area of rectangle = length × width
• Area = 28 × 15
• Area = 420 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the rectangular basketball court is 420 square metres

question_text: A bookshelf is shaped like a rectangular prism with a length of 1.2 metres, a width of 0.4 metres, and a height of 1.8 metres. What is the volume of space inside the bookshelf?
solution:
• Volume of a rectangular prism = length × width × height
• Volume = 1.2 × 0.4 × 1.8
• Volume = 0.48 × 1.8 = 0.864 m³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the bookshelf is 0.864 m³

question_text: A hexagonal pavilion has a regular hexagonal floor. Each side of the hexagon measures 4 metres. The perpendicular distance from the centre of the hexagon to the midpoint of any side is 3.46 metres. What is the area of the pavilion floor?
solution:
• A regular hexagon can be divided into 6 congruent triangles from the centre
• Each triangle has a base of 4 metres (one side of the hexagon) and a height of 3.46 metres (the perpendicular distance from centre to side)
• Area of one triangle = ½ × base × height = ½ × 4 × 3.46 = 6.92 m²
• Total area of hexagon = 6 × 6.92 = 41.52 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the hexagonal floor has an area of 41.52 m²

visual_data.description: A regular hexagon with all sides labeled as 4 m, showing the perpendicular distance from the centre to one side labeled as 3.46 m

question_text: A rectangular picture frame has a length of 40 cm and a width of 25 cm. What is the perimeter of the picture frame?
solution:
• Perimeter of a rectangle = 2 × (length + width)
• Perimeter = 2 × (40 + 25) = 2 × 65 = 130 cm
• Therefore, the answer is B because the perimeter is calculated by adding all four sides of the rectangle

question_text: A trapezium-shaped window has parallel sides of length 2.4 metres and 1.6 metres. The perpendicular distance between these parallel sides is 1.5 metres. What is the area of the window?
solution:
• Area of trapezium = ½ × (sum of parallel sides) × height
• Area = ½ × (2.4 + 1.6) × 1.5
• Area = ½ × 4.0 × 1.5 = 2.0 × 1.5 = 3.0 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the trapezium-shaped window is 3.0 m²

question_text: A cylindrical water bottle has a diameter of 7 cm and a height of 20 cm. What is the volume of water it can hold? (Use π ≈ 22/7)
solution:
• Radius = diameter ÷ 2 = 7 ÷ 2 = 3.5 cm
• Volume of cylinder = π × r² × h
• Volume = (22/7) × (3.5)² × 20
• Volume = (22/7) × 12.25 × 20
• Volume = (22/7) × 245 = 22 × 35 = 770 cm³
• Therefore, the answer is B because the volume of the cylindrical water bottle is 770 cm³

question_text: A triangular sail on a yacht has a base of 4.8 metres and a height of 6 metres. What is the area of the sail?
solution:
• Area of triangle = ½ × base × height
• Area = ½ × 4.8 × 6
• Area = ½ × 28.8 = 14.4 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the triangular sail is 14.4 m²

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of birds observed at a nature reserve during three seasons:

| Bird Type | Spring | Summer | Autumn |
|-----------|--------|--------|--------|
| Parrots   | 45     | 38     | 52     |
| Cockatoos | 62     | 71     | 58     |
| Finches   | 33     | 29     | 41     |

How many more Cockatoos than Finches were observed across all three seasons combined?
solution:
• First, calculate total Cockatoos: 62 + 71 + 58 = 191
• Then, calculate total Finches: 33 + 29 + 41 = 103
• Find the difference: 191 - 103 = 88
• Therefore, the answer is B because 88 more Cockatoos than Finches were observed across all three seasons

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of fossils discovered at an archaeological site during four excavation periods:

| Fossil Type | Period 1 | Period 2 | Period 3 | Period 4 |
|-------------|----------|----------|----------|----------|
| Trilobites  | 24       | 18       | 30       | 22       |
| Ammonites   | 16       | 25       | 20       | 19       |
| Brachiopods | 12       | 15       | 18       | 15       |

In which period was the total number of fossils discovered exactly 25% more than the total discovered in Period 1?
solution:
• First, calculate the total fossils in Period 1: 24 + 16 + 12 = 52 fossils
• Calculate 25% more than Period 1: 52 + (0.25 × 52) = 52 + 13 = 65 fossils
• Calculate totals for each period:
  - Period 2: 18 + 25 + 15 = 58 fossils
  - Period 3: 30 + 20 + 18 = 68 fossils
  - Period 4: 22 + 19 + 15 = 56 fossils
• None of the periods have exactly 65 fossils
• Therefore, the answer is E because no period matches the required total of 65 fossils

question_text:
The table shows the number of medals won by different countries at a swimming competition:

| Country   | Gold | Silver | Bronze |
|-----------|------|--------|--------|
| Australia | 12   | 8      | 6      |
| Japan     | 9    | 11     | 7      |
| Canada    | 7    | 6      | 10     |

How many medals in total did Japan win?
solution:
• Japan won 9 Gold medals, 11 Silver medals, and 7 Bronze medals
• Total medals = 9 + 11 + 7 = 27
• Therefore, the answer is B because Japan won 27 medals in total

question_text:
The table shows the number of passengers on different flights departing from an airport:

| Flight | Passengers |
|--------|------------|
| FL101  | 145        |
| FL202  | 178        |
| FL303  | 162        |
| FL404  | 155        |

How many more passengers were on flight FL202 than on flight FL101?
solution:
• Find the number of passengers on FL202: 178
• Find the number of passengers on FL101: 145
• Calculate the difference: 178 - 145 = 33
• Therefore, the answer is B because there were 33 more passengers on FL202 than on FL101

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of vehicles that crossed a bridge during morning peak hour:

| Vehicle Type | Number |
|--------------|--------|
| Cars         | 245    |
| Motorcycles  | 68     |
| Buses        | 32     |
| Trucks       | 45     |

If motorcycles and buses together represent what percentage of the total vehicles, what is the answer (rounded to the nearest whole number)?
solution:
• First, find the total number of motorcycles and buses: 68 + 32 = 100
• Next, find the total number of all vehicles: 245 + 68 + 32 + 45 = 390
• Calculate the percentage: (100 ÷ 390) × 100 = 25.64%
• Round to the nearest whole number: 26%
• Therefore, the answer is B because motorcycles and buses represent 26% of total vehicles

question_text:
The table shows the number of books borrowed from a library by different age groups during one month:

| Age Group | Week 1 | Week 2 | Week 3 | Week 4 |
|-----------|--------|--------|--------|--------|
| Children  | 45     | 52     | 48     | 55     |
| Teens     | 38     | 41     | 39     | 46     |
| Adults    | 67     | 71     | 69     | 73     |

If the library charges a processing fee of $0.50 per book borrowed, what was the total processing fee collected from the Teens age group for the entire month?
solution:
• First, calculate the total number of books borrowed by Teens: 38 + 41 + 39 + 46 = 164 books
• Then, multiply by the processing fee per book: 164 × $0.50 = $82.00
• Therefore, the answer is B because the total processing fee collected from Teens was $82.00

question_text:
The table shows the number of different types of sandwiches sold at a café during lunch service:

| Sandwich Type | Number Sold |
|---------------|-------------|
| Chicken       | 34          |
| Vegetarian    | 28          |
| Ham           | 41          |
| Tuna          | 22          |

How many more Ham sandwiches than Tuna sandwiches were sold?
solution:
• Find the number of Ham sandwiches sold: 41
• Find the number of Tuna sandwiches sold: 22
• Calculate the difference: 41 - 22 = 19
• Therefore, the answer is B because 19 more Ham sandwiches than Tuna sandwiches were sold.

question_text: A hiking trail is marked on a number line from 0 km to 3 km. Rest Station P is located at 5/6 km and Rest Station Q is at 2 1/3 km. A water fountain is positioned exactly 2/3 of the distance from P to Q. At what point on the number line is the water fountain located?
solution:
• First, convert Q to an improper fraction: 2 1/3 = 7/3 km
• Find the distance from P to Q: 7/3 - 5/6. Convert to common denominator: 14/6 - 5/6 = 9/6 = 3/2 km
• Find 2/3 of this distance: 2/3 × 3/2 = 6/6 = 1 km
• Add this to P's position: 5/6 + 1 = 5/6 + 6/6 = 11/6 = 1 5/6 km
• Therefore, the answer is C because the water fountain is at 1 5/6 km

question_text: A music streaming app shows song progress on a timeline from 0 to 1 representing the full song. Point M marks where the chorus begins at 2/9 of the song, and Point N marks where the bridge starts at 7/12 of the song. What fraction of the song plays between the start of the chorus and the start of the bridge?
solution:
• Find the distance between M and N: N - M = 7/12 - 2/9
• Convert to common denominator (LCD = 36): 7/12 = 21/36 and 2/9 = 8/36
• Calculate: 21/36 - 8/36 = 13/36
• Check if it simplifies: 13 is prime and doesn't divide 36, so 13/36 is in simplest form
• Therefore, the answer is B because 13/36 of the song plays between the chorus and bridge

question_text: A robot moves along a track marked from 0 to 2 metres. It starts at position 3/4 and moves to position 1 and 1/2. How far did the robot travel?
solution:
• Convert 1 and 1/2 to an improper fraction: 1 and 1/2 = 3/2
• Convert 3/4 to have denominator 4: 3/4 = 3/4
• Find common denominator: 3/2 = 6/4
• Calculate distance: 6/4 - 3/4 = 3/4
• Therefore, the answer is B because the robot travelled 3/4 metres

visual_data.description: A horizontal number line from 0 to 2, with major tick marks at 0, 1, and 2. Point marked at 3/4 (labeled 'Start') and point marked at 1 and 1/2 (labeled 'End'). Arrow showing movement from Start to End.

answer_verification.reasoning: The robot moves from 3/4 metres to 1 1/2 metres. Distance = 1 1/2 - 3/4 = 3/2 - 3/4 = 6/4 - 3/4 = 3/4 metres. The solution is mathematically correct. All other options are incorrect: A) 1/4 is too small, C) 1/2 is too small, D) and E) are far too large for a movement between these two positions on a 0-2 metre track.

question_text:
A library tracks the number of books borrowed by students each day. The table shows the borrowing data for one week:

| Day | Fiction | Non-Fiction | Total |
|---------|---------|-------------|-------|
| Monday | 12 | 8 | 20 |
| Tuesday | 15 | 10 | 25 |
| Wednesday | 18 | 7 | 25 |
| Thursday | 14 | 11 | 25 |
| Friday | 20 | 15 | 35 |

How many more Fiction books than Non-Fiction books were borrowed during the entire week?
solution:
• Total Fiction books borrowed: 12 + 15 + 18 + 14 + 20 = 79 books
• Total Non-Fiction books borrowed: 8 + 10 + 7 + 11 + 15 = 51 books
• Difference: 79 - 51 = 28 books
• Therefore, the answer is B because 28 more Fiction books than Non-Fiction books were borrowed during the week.

question_text:
A swimming coach records the training times for her squad. The table shows the weekly training hours for different age groups:

| Age Group | Pool Hours | Gym Hours | Total Sessions |
|-----------|------------|-----------|----------------|
| 8-9 years | 3 | 1 | 4 |
| 10-11 years | 4.5 | 1.5 | 5 |
| 12-13 years | 6 | 2 | 6 |
| 14-15 years | 7.5 | 2.5 | 7 |

Sarah is in the 10-11 years age group and trains for 8 weeks. What is the total number of hours (pool and gym combined) that Sarah spends training over this period?
solution:
• Find Sarah's age group (10-11 years) in the table
• Pool hours per week: 4.5 hours, Gym hours per week: 1.5 hours
• Total hours per week: 4.5 + 1.5 = 6 hours
• Total hours over 8 weeks: 6 × 8 = 48 hours
• Therefore, the answer is C because Sarah trains 6 hours per week for 8 weeks, giving 48 hours total

question_text:
A bakery tracks the number of pastries sold during a weekend. The table shows the sales data:

| Pastry Type | Saturday | Sunday |
|-------------|----------|--------|
| Croissants  | 45       | 38     |
| Muffins     | 52       | 47     |
| Danishes    | 28       | 35     |
| Scones      | 31       | 29     |

Each croissant costs $4.50 and each Danish costs $5.00. What was the total revenue from croissants and Danishes sold across both days?
solution:
• Total croissants sold: 45 + 38 = 83 croissants
• Revenue from croissants: 83 × $4.50 = $373.50
• Total Danishes sold: 28 + 35 = 63 Danishes
• Revenue from Danishes: 63 × $5.00 = $315.00
• Total revenue: $373.50 + $315.00 = $688.50
• Therefore, the answer is B because the combined revenue from croissants and Danishes over both days is $688.50

question_text:
A school canteen tracks the number of sandwiches sold during lunch breaks. The table shows the sales for one week:

| Day | Cheese | Ham | Salad |
|---------|--------|-----|-------|
| Monday | 12 | 18 | 8 |
| Tuesday | 15 | 16 | 10 |
| Wednesday | 14 | 20 | 9 |
| Thursday | 11 | 17 | 12 |
| Friday | 16 | 22 | 11 |

How many sandwiches were sold on Wednesday?
solution:
• Find the Wednesday row in the table
• Add all sandwich types sold on Wednesday: Cheese (14) + Ham (20) + Salad (9)
• 14 + 20 + 9 = 43
• Therefore, the answer is B because 43 sandwiches were sold on Wednesday

question_text: A scientist is monitoring temperature changes on a scale from 0°C to 4°C. At time T₁, the temperature is at 2/3°C. At time T₂, it reaches 2 and 5/6°C. The scientist needs to record exactly 1/4 of this temperature increase. What value should be recorded?
solution:
• First, find the total temperature increase: 2 and 5/6 - 2/3
• Convert to improper fractions: 17/6 - 2/3
• Find common denominator: 17/6 - 4/6 = 13/6°C
• Calculate 1/4 of the increase: 13/6 × 1/4 = 13/24°C
• Therefore, the answer is B because one-quarter of the temperature increase is 13/24°C
